class_notes:
This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement: -Tradition-Other.
This course explores the ideas of Taoism (Daoism), one of the major philosophical traditions of ancient China. We will be thinking through what the texts meant in their original context, and what they might mean for us today. We begin with a close reading of two different translations of the Tao Te Ching (Daodejing) by Lao Tzu (Laozi), the principal classic text. Themes include: ideas about language, political philosophy, relativism, the cultivation of the body, desire, gender, and cosmology. We will then read selections from the Taoist text Chuang Tzu (Zhuangzi), and a brief selection of later Taoist works, especially poetry. We will then focus on two themes: the martial tradition and the utopian tradition, that is, what these Taoist texts have to say about war and violence, and about the ideal peaceful society. We will discover that "going with the flow" is never a simple matter.
course_description: This course will explore classic religious texts in depth, developing skills to interpret sacred, philosophical and ethical works. Social, cultural, and/or philosophical contexts at work will provide interpretive frameworks.
